prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: target_1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe CO 1-0, search for outflow wings Cover CN 1-0 in second baseband Observe 3mm continuum in all basebands

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity: The integrated CO flux density is predicted based on the CO-FIR relation (e.g., Carilli & Walter 2013). We assume that the CO emission is resolved over 3 beams, and set the sensitivity to be able to detect outflow wings of 4%-7% of 1/3 of the line peak flux and >~300km/s width at 5-10 sigma/beam Sensitivities are calculated at the observed-frame frequency of CO, and for 100km/s velocity bins.
- Imaging: The outflow will only be marginally resolved at best, so snapshot uv coverage would be sufficient. As such, the integration time is solely determined by the required sensitivity level. The goal is to detect an outflow from the nucleus, not to map the entire galaxy. Thus, the ACA is not necssary.
- Correlator Setup: The goal is to detect broad spectral features of few hundred km/s. As such, the broadest bandwidth FDM spectral setting is selected for all bands. The CO line is cenered in one baseband in the USB, and the second baseband is set adjacent at a lower frequency and will cover the CN 1-0 line The third and fourth basebands cover the LSB to maximize sensitivity towards the underlying continuum emission, and to enable detection/stacking of faint serendiptious lines
- Calibration: The standard calibration will be fully sufficient for this band 3 detection experiment
- Bandpass: The standard bandpass and sideband ratio calibration will be sufficient.
- Scheduling/time constraints: None.
- Data rate: We use the standard data rate and dump time for these observations. Lowering the data rate would require to compromise spectral line observing by selecting a lower spectral resolution. Online spectral smoothing by a factor of 2 in frequency would be acceptable if advised in phase 2.
Special constraints on standard observing modes: The overheads for this program are significant, but are standard for the adopted calibration scheme.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: To investigate AGN-driven outflows as a tracer of AGN feedback, we propose the CO(1-0) line observations of type 2 AGNs, for which the ionized gas outflows are detected with the large [O III] velocity (i.e., line-of-sight velocity offset > 200 km/s, or FWHM > 1000 km/s). Driven from a large number of ~23,000 type 2 AGNs at z < 0.1 based on our statistical study using the SDSS spectra (Bae & Woo 2013), these rare AGNs with strong signatures of ionized gas outflows (< 0.5%) are one of the best suites for investigating AGN feedback in action in the present-day. By investigating the presence of high velocity (broad) component of the CO line, and comparing it with the ionized gas outflows and numerical simulations, we will investigate the physical properties of outflows to probe the role of gas outflows as AGN feedback. For this pilot project we request 4 hours of Band 3 observations for a sample of 5 AGNs selected based on the AKARI FIR detections.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Seoul National University
